justification: The article states that "intertemporal choice is often evaluated using pen-and-paper questionnaires (Kirby and Maraković 1996)", indicating this questionnaire is an instrument for measuring temporal discounting.
It notes that intertemporal choice is also assessed with "computerized tasks e.g. (Peters and Büchel 2009)", showing these computerized tasks are used to measure the construct.

The text explains that "the most common [measure] being a discount rate that describes the steepness in value reduction over time", identifying the discount-rate parameter as the measure of temporal discounting.

Under model-agnostic measures, it states "The area under the curve (AUC) provides a measure of an individual's overall level of TD" (Myerson et al., 2001), linking AUC to quantifying temporal discounting.
The article introduces Eq. 1 where "P(LL) is the proportion of LL choice", describing this proportion as "one simple but straightforward method" to quantify intertemporal choice behavior.
